text:
I can hack the lock for the private elevator.
You get her to tell you where the elevator is, and head down there, leaving her sitting at the bar.
It's unguarded, but there's a keycard slot by the call button. Luckily, you have just the thing to deal with that.
You push back your sleeve and work a finger under the dial of your watch. At the press of a tiny catch, a small disc falls into your palm. You slap it against the card reader, where it sticks.
You check your watch—good, it's working on it. Five—four—three—two….
The light turns green. The doors of the elevator slide open.
I want to try and talk to Hercules himself.

If I tell him what happened to Jay, maybe he'll help.
"Marco," you say, stepping out from the shadows. He turns, confused—how do you know his name?
"Hey, I know you."
"Wait," you say quickly. "I have something important to tell you. About Jay."
His hand hovers over his radio. 100 is silent and still beside the pair of you, watching to see how your gambit plays out.
You tell Marco—not everything, he'd never believe that—but the important things. That Jay is dead. That he'd been killed to get rid of evidence, because the company is doing things it shouldn't and Jay got caught up in that, got taken advantage of. You show him the token.
He looks at it for a long moment, and for dignity's sake you avert your eyes from his face. Then he puts it in his pocket, and, in silence, takes the security pass off his belt, and hands it to you, and walks away.
"Nicely handled," murmurs 100. "Let's go."
Look around for more info.

Stay very calm and try to reason with him.
"I didn't do it," you say, steadily. "Think about this. I was tied up in the back of that van; how could I have got out unless someone else intervened? And this woman here works for people who don't like your boss. Not Hercules. Your [i]other[/i] boss."
If we're told to kill him, 100 had better stay out of my way.

Flattery.
"It would be a waste of your considerable skills to have you here not doing anything, don't you think?"
"You're banking on my vanity?" he says.
Try to talk to him.
I need to persuade her that she can talk to me.

Respond with a threat.
"Big words for someone who's about to die," says Angel, amused.
Take them both on; I'm not letting an innocent get hurt if I can help it.

Sneak into the building, then pick the lock. It'll be easier since I have the right tools.
You spot your chance to get inside when a delivery man approaches the front door. You follow him in, shield yourself from the super's view behind his stack of parcels, and make a break for the stairs.

Use my tech skills to create a distraction that will let me steal the building super's spare set of keys.
You lean casually up against the wall outside and get out your phone. Right. Let's see who has unsecured networks.
The Hendersons on floor six is the answer. A little more work, and you're set up to make a call to the superintendent that will seem like it's coming from them.
Of course, he might know these people well enough to question an unknown voice,
What if neither of them make it? I've got to help.
I'll try to take him out, then consider my options.

Makeup for quick disguise.
A large palette of various shades, which you can use to contour and emphasize facial features to make you look, if not completely different, at least enough to confuse eyewitnesses.

Use a gadget.
You don't carry IIA ID—too dangerous if you were to ever get captured. But you do have something that does the job. "Mr. Petrovich, I'm with Interpol," you say. "I'm going to reach into my pocket, and show you my ID, okay?"
Excruciatingly slowly, you let your hand drift down to your pocket.

Misdirect their suspicions with a complicated explanation.
You begin to explain that there would be no benefit in you including any salacious personal details into your tech article, combining it with a lecture on audience engagement in digital media that should make anyone's eyes glaze over.

I don't care what they say, I want him dead.
Maybe you can arrange for something to 'go wrong' during the extraction. It's so easy for things to go wrong in the heat of the moment, after all.

Make an acrobatic leap over everyone's head so I can grab Faustus.
In a single bound, you jump up onto the counter behind you. You run along the edge, leap to the next counter, up onto an industrial fridge and then
This is too sudden for me.

I…need a nap now.
In the wake of that intense focus comes an exhaustion so profound you feel you could just curl up on the floor and pass out.
But, probably best not to do it here and suffocate on chemical fumes. You should get out of here.

Eyes…
Your eyes are:
"I'm sorry. I did use you. But it was necessary." I'll make my apology and leave.
I believe he deserves this. Consider it a punishment.

"I just think you should be careful of Crystal…."
Hex's eyebrows nearly disappear into their hairline. "[i]Excuse me?[/i]"
You probably shouldn't have said anything. "I can't really explain, but people like that can be dangerous," you try.
"I am not listening to you talk like that about a friend of mine," Hex says, arms crossed.

Try to grab and wrestle him.
He goes for your gun arm, trying to force it up and away from him.

Injure him, but leave him alive.
Fine. He gets to live. But you're going to leave him with something to remember you by.
You pull out your gun.

I'd do it again, but wish it wasn't necessary.
The circumstances left you with no other choice, and you don't regret the death itself. But you would rather not have been in that position. You do always try to keep killing as a last resort. That way you can at least tell yourself there's a difference between you and the people at the other end of the gun.

He seems very focused on his job—I'll come at it from that angle.
"It sounds like you've had a lot on your plate," you say. "I hope this tragedy isn't going to throw a spanner in the gears."

"You should be flattered. I don't normally do this."
"I bet you say that to

Choose to wear salwar kameez.
The long tunic has beautifully intricate embroidery around the neck, hem, and sleeves.

Tell Vicki that she should leave the investigation part to me.
She doesn't look too pleased.

An elegant and modest dress.
It's not a design that shouts for attention, but every detail of the color, fabric, and tailoring is perfect for you.

Take an understanding approach to soothe him. I think the key is how personally he takes this.
"Look, I know about how hard the problems your company had last year must have been on you. It makes sense you'd want to do something that would restore your reputation."
Unused to being forceful in my manner.
I joined the police to fight crime—this seemed the next logical step.
"Yes, I get that." I can definitely relate to him putting work first.

Ask about Azazel—though she may be reluctant to give me much detail on someone so powerful.
"It's dangerous for someone like me to talk about my employers," she says, wary. "Especially to you people."
"I know. I'm not asking for name and address. Just…what are they like?"
Terrify the man into surrendering.

Make as if you're going along with it and then attack Peter.
"Okay," you say, putting a nervous tremor into your voice. You start to walk towards Peter, uncomfortably aware that behind you, the others are closing in, blocking the corridor. "I don't know what's happening, but I don't want any trouble."

Pace in a circle.
Nervous energy courses through you; you make a few laps in an attempt to burn some of it off. 100 watches you.
Talk to Hex again.

"I'm inclined to withhold judgment until I see it out in the world."
He lets out a bark of laughter. "That may be sooner than you think!"
"It seems as if the whole project has moved quickly.

I can knock it right out the sky with a well-thrown projectile.
What you wouldn't give for a gun right now. But you work with what you've got. You will need a good vantage point, though—somewhere you can be at eye level with or above the drone.
You keep driving, keeping one eye on the rear mirror, and the other on the buildings lining the road. Finally you find what you need. An alleyway, tall buildings, and an external fire escape. So, here's your location. But the next part is going to have to be perfect.
"I'm going to make a sharp turn," you tell Vicki. "When I stop the car, get out, lean against the car, look like you're waiting for someone. Don't look in my direction."
She starts to respond, her words cut off in a yelp as you make a screeching turn into the alleyway. There's a window of a few seconds before the drone follows you in. You slam the brakes on, throw the car door open, and leap out, grabbing the metal railing of the fire escape and hauling yourself up. Vicki is slower to respond, but she does as you said, stepping out just as the black shape buzzes around the corner. As you'd hoped, it focuses on her, settling into a holding pattern. Knowing you're out of the view of its cameras, you start climbing the fire escape.

I'll ingratiate myself with the group and slip in a few questions.
The next time you see a group in the canteen after a shift change, you go and join the table.
Working with computer systems.

Sit on the floor and start my meditation routine in an attempt to soften the thoughts.
Breathe in, breathe out, just like your therapist showed you. You might owe him an apology for scoffing when he first suggested this.
But although you do start to feel calmer, you can't muffle one persistent thought.

"Can you get into their network and find out anything else?"
"Not from here. Their networks are isolated—I'd need you to get me in from the inside. And I don't think you can pull that off right now without blowing your cover."

I quietly suggest that they seem to be regretting it now.
They frown.
I'll admit I want him dead, but I don't know if I can pull the trigger myself.

"I'm not sure about this."
"I'd be surprised if you were.

"To say goodbye."
"I didn't want to just vanish, after everything."
My fear of failure.
"Don't worry, it's all going to be all right," I say soothingly.
"It's such an honor to be working with you," I say. Flattery will get you everywhere, right?
"How did I get out of there? Where am I?"

Make an emotional appeal.
turn your precious project to the worst possible ends. Once again, it will all be taken out of your hands.

Well, this just got exciting.
And to think you were starting to get bored with all the undercover work.

"You're joking, right? After how much you messed me around on this mission?"
"If I managed this at all, it's in spite of you keeping me in the dark on important details and running your tests like I'm some kind of rat in a maze," you snap.
The Director's response is so icy you're surprised frost doesn't form on the screen. "Be careful, Agent. I do not take insubordination lightly. And you should understand that you will always be tested, because we need the best."
Order her to get out of here.

How childish. Still, if I can hide my disapproval, gaining favor now might be worth it later.
You push away your actual feelings and try to look

Close and slow.
You put your arms around The Newcomer and the two of you sway slowly to the music.

Dissuade their suspicions with a hint of menace.
"I'm not interested in digging into your private affairs. Do you have any reason to believe I'm being that unprofessional? If you feel you need to make a complaint to my head office, go ahead," you say, trying to convey that this would be a bad idea.
Try to use the neuro-disruptor to daze him for a second.
I want to find out more about Hercules's bodyguards, the twins.

"I'm truly impressed by the vision behind it."
"And," you continue, "with the speed in which you've managed to get the project to this point.

An elegant and formal three-piece.
It's not a design that shouts for attention, but the Saville Row tailoring is exquisite.

I will make brutally clear the kind of danger she's in.
"Think back to what just happened," you say, keeping your voice low and even, but fixing her with an intense stare. "If I hadn't been there, they would have gutted you. These people are willing to kill. I can deal with that. You can't."

Maybe the neighbors know something? It may be worth trying to coax them to talk about Atkinson.
You step back into the corridor, closing the door gently behind you, just in time to see one of the doors at the far end of the corridor swing shut. Someone's home. Perhaps that's as good a place to start as any.
When you knock on the door, a man answers, gives you a disapproving look, and says, "We're not buying anything."
From somewhere behind him, the voice of an elderly woman says, "[i]Who is it[/i]?" in Mandarin. You catch a glimpse of her over his shoulder.
"[i]No one, Mom,[/i]" he replies, trying to close the door.

"Sure you'll be okay?" I ask—I'm concerned, but I have to get moving.
"I've had worse," he says with a proud tilt of the head. "Go on. Get going."
You nod, and head for the doorway.

I'm pleased, but roll my eyes to cover my true reaction.
What's wrong with you? That's not even a good line!

"How difficult is it to implant and remove?"
"The implantation is pretty quick. It's done using a sort of injector gun. You can do it in under a minute. Then of course you'd have an adjustment period of several weeks where the implant's functionality is gradually brought online, so it works up a baseline for the user's vital readings."
"So it couldn't start working immediately?" you interject.
"We would never advise…"
"But could it?"
"I…uh. Technically?" Hex squints at you, confused.

The MegaMeat Supreme Cheeseburger Meal.
A glorious stack of beef and cholesterol that's probably contributed to many a cardiologist's second home.
"No, we should have had more help on this mission."

…while we were on a hiking trip.
You had just reached the peak, where you could see the hills rolling away from you, and the sunlight caught in his hair as you held out the ring.
I'll take that.

By cheating. I'll use my x-ray specs to read the cards.
Under the pretense of adjusting your glasses, you push a tiny button on the side of their frames. Immediately the scene in front of you is outlined in an eerie blue glow. The tables and chairs and even the people become semi-translucent, skeletons shrouded in a vague cloud of body. Most importantly, you can now see what's printed on the other side of everyone's cards.
With this help, you start playing. You're careful not to seem too lucky; you lose the first few hands on purpose and fold on a pair of kings. You note the position of cards, and carefully begin to arrange things to your best advantage.
The other players are soon out. That leaves you, the elderly gentleman, and the woman, Frau Bergmann.
There's a pair of sevens on the table, along with the two of clubs and nine of diamonds. She's got a nine in her hand to give her a two pair; he's got a seven to give him three of a kind.
You consider your hand—ten of hearts, eight of clubs. Useless, unless you're very lucky with the river card.
And you've always been one to make your own luck.

Let Angel do what she wants.
Angel strolls casually to the security booth. "One thing I wanted to ask."
"Yea—agh!"
Angel lunges—grabbing the man across the face to muffle his yells, and striking the ring into his neck. It takes a few long seconds before his struggles weaken. You glance towards the door, fingers tracing the cool metal of the gun in your waistband.
As the man passes fully into unconsciousness, Angel lets him drop to the floor with a painful-sounding thud.
"Let's hurry," you say, already heading through the door.
"You're welcome," says Angel, striding after you.
Make him too scared to try anything.
"Unfortunately, we're stuck with each other," I say coldly.

Try to appeal to him based on our friendship—maybe some part of him is still conscious.
"Listen to me," you say, backing away. "Look at me, Gareth. You don't want to hurt me, do you? If you can hear me, [i]wake up[/i]."
He keeps moving towards you, watching your movements, ready to strike.

"You know, your henchwoman here tried to kill me just the other day."
"I'm sure you understand that these things are never personal," the voice growls, as Angel scowls at you. "I hope we can put any past misunderstandings behind us and look to our mutual benefit."

Talk her into surrendering.
You cough loudly, and she spins the chair around.

"Save me a dance for when I come back?"
"Promise," he says with a grin. "But I'm not guaranteeing anything when it comes to my dancing skills." He hesitates, smile fading. "Are you sure you're alright?"

"No, it's understandable."
She gives a thin smile.
Rush in, making myself the center of the scene.

Make a thorough and thoughtful search of the apartment.
You snap on a pair of latex gloves.
"To cheer you up?"
I hope they go for the more difficult option—I'd like to see him held to account for more than just me.

I vowed I'd avenge him, whatever it took.
In those dark days directly after the attack, sometimes the only thing that kept you going was the promise you made to yourself that you would make DIABLO pay.

Try to intimidate them into leaving.
One brother has a gun trained on you. "Get on the ground," he growls at you. "You too, unless you want your friend dead."

Loafers.
Comfortable, convenient, and concealing a steel toe cap.
Yes, Hercules is going to tell me what I need to know if I have to beat it out of him.
Attack while we have the chance to take them down with a quick brutal strike.

"If I recall the story, that was a trick."
It's probably not a good idea to get sarcastic at him, but you can't resist. But he doesn't even seem to pay attention to what you said, plowing ahead.

First I want to retract my previous hints.
You tell her that you were lying before. That you really are just a journalist; that you thought giving yourself an air of mystery would help in your attempt to find out what she knew.
She seems to believe you, but it's also clear that she's not happy about it.

Using my speed and agility.
You use every ounce of agility and guile you can muster, ducking and weaving and feinting. Within seconds you're soaked in sweat from the exertion,
An Indian man with long black hair coiled into a bun.
Sneak up on her and choke her out.
